column20: gave Kilkenny a charter as a town in 1207. By the late thirteenth century
column21: Kilkenny was under Hiberno-Norman control. The Statutes of Kilkenny
column23: aimed to curb the decline of the Hiberno-Norman Lordship of Ireland. In 1609

column1: Kilkenny was a brewing centre from the late seventeenth century
column2: and still houses a number of breweries.

column1: The Heritage Council offices are at Church Lane in the former Bishop's Palace. The seat of the Roman Catholic Bishop of Ossory is at St Mary's Cathedral and the Church of Ireland Bishop of Cashel and Ossory is at St Canice's Cathedral.
== Toponymy ==
Kilkenny is the anglicised version of the Irish Cill Chainnigh
column2: meaning Cell/Church of Cainneach or Canice. This relates to a church built in honour of St. Canice
column3: an Ulsterman
column4: on the hill now containing St. Canice's Cathedral and the round tower. This seems to be the first major settlement. The early Christian origin of the round tower suggests an early ecclesiastical foundation at Kilkenny.

column1: Ceall-Cainnigh was for the most part burned.
The Annals of the Four Masters recorded Kilkenny in 1085. Prior to this time the early 6th-century territory was known as Osraighe
column2: referring to the whole district or the capital. The Four Masters entry was the first instance where the capital was called Ceall-Cainnigh (modernized Kilkenny). Cill Chainnigh was a major monastic centre from at least the eighth century. There is no mention of Cill Chainnigh in the lives of Cainnech of Aghaboe
column3: Ciar√°n of Saighir or any of the early annals of Ireland suggesting that Cill Chainnigh was not of ancient civil importance.

column1: == City status ==
Officially 'the Municipal District of Kilkenny City'
column2: Kilkenny does not have a city council under the Local Government Reform Act 2014
column3: but it is referred to as a city under the same act.

column1: Traditionally Kilkenny had been referred to as a city
column2: and this has its roots in local usage
column3: deriving from a Royal Charter granted by King James I of England in 1609.

column1: Historically
column2: city status in the United Kingdom
column3: and before that in the Kingdom of Ireland
column4: was a ceremonial designation awarded by the Crown. It carried more prestige than the alternative municipal titles "borough" or "town"
column5: but gave no extra legal powers (Historically
column6: the qualifying factor was the presence of a cathedral
column7: resulting in some very small cities such as Wells
column8: with a population 12

column1: A city in Irish law has special legal meaning with corresponding powers for local government. From a local government perspective
column2: Kilkenny was not administered as a city since at least 1840. The present-day legal
column3: political and administrative jurisdictions in Ireland are set out in the Local Government Reform Act 2014.

column1: While the present-day settlement is administered as a municipal district
column2: the appellation "city" is an emotive subject in Kilkenny
column3: and TDs Phil Hogan and John McGuinness successfully lobbied that when "boroughs" were renamed "towns" under the Local Government Act 2001
column4: Kilkenny could continue to be referred to as a "city".  Accordingly
column5: a clause was added to the 2001 bill:

column1: the continued use of the description city in relation to Kilkenny
column2: to the extent that that description was used before the establishment day.

column1: == History ==
Kilkenny's foundation began with an early sixth-century ecclesiastical settlement
column2: with a church built in honour of St. Canice. Now St. Canice's Cathedral
column3: this was a major monastic centre from at least the eighth century. The Annals of the Four Masters recorded the first reference Cill Chainnigh in 1085. Prehistoric activity has been recorded
column4: suggesting intermittent settlement activity in the area in the Mesolithic and Bronze Age. Information on the history of Kilkenny can be found from newspapers
column5: photographs
column6: letters
column8: manuscripts and archaeology. Kilkenny is documented in manuscripts from the 13th century onwards and one of the most important of these is Liber Primus Kilkenniensis.

column1: The Kings of Ossory
column2: O'Carrolls and Fitzpatricks
column3: had residence around Cill Chainnigh. The seat of the diocese of Kingdom of Osraige was moved from Aghaboe to Cill Chainnigh. Following the Norman invasion of Ireland
column4: Richard Strongbow
column5: as Lord of Leinster
column6: established a castle near modern-day Kilkenny Castle. William Marshall began the development of the town of Kilkenny and a series of walls to protect the burghers. By the late thirteenth century
column7: Kilkenny was under Norman-Irish control. The original ecclesiastical centre at St. Canice's Cathedral became known as Irishtown and the Anglo-Norman borough inside the wall came to be known as Hightown.

column1: A remarkable early trial for witchcraft was that of Kilkenny resident Alice Kyteler (involving also her maidservant
column2: Petronilla de Meath) instigated by the then Bishop of Ossory
column3: Richard de Ledrede

column1: The Hiberno-Norman presence in Kilkenny was deeply shaken by the Black Death
column2: which arrived in 1348. The Statutes of Kilkenny passed at Kilkenny in 1367
column3: aimed to curb the decline of the Hiberno-Norman Lordship of Ireland. In 1609 King James I of England granted Kilkenny a Royal Charter giving it the status of a city. Following the Rebellion of 1641
column4: the Irish Catholic Confederation
column5: also known as the "Confederation of Kilkenny"
column6: was based in Kilkenny and lasted until the Cromwellian conquest of Ireland in 1649. James II of England spent most of the winter months from November 1689 until January 1690 at Kilkenny
column7: residing in the castle.The Kilkenny Design Workshops were opened in 1965 and in 1967 the Marquess of Ormonde presented Kilkenny Castle to the people of Kilkenny. Today
column8: it has a lively cultural scene
column9: with annual events including the Kilkenny Arts Week Festival in the last two weeks of August
column10: and the Cat Laughs Comedy Festival at the beginning of June. Kilkenny is also where the Irish ale
column12: was first brewed. There is now a brewery tour on the foundations of the original brewery. Kilkenny is referred to as the Marble City
column13: and people from Kilkenny are often referred to as 'Cats'. The seat of the Roman Catholic Bishop of Ossory is at St. Mary's Cathedral and the Church of Ireland Bishop of Cashel and Ossory is at St. Canice's Cathedral.

column1: Kilkenny is also the site of Ireland's earliest recorded witch trial. Occurring in 1324
column2: the trial involved Dame Alice de Kyteler and her servant Petronella de Meath.  Petronella would be the first person recorded in Ireland to be burned alive at the stake for witchcraft
column3: after Dame Alice presumably fled the country. This trial was also one of the earliest recorded witch burnings in Europe and inspires much folklore about the possibility of the ghosts of Alice and Petronella haunting downtown Kilkenny. Alice's house
column4: Kyteler's Inn
column5: still stands and is now a pub.

column1: == Geography ==
Kilkenny is situated in the Nore Valley on both banks of the River Nore
column2: at the centre of County Kilkenny in the province of Leinster in the south-east of Ireland. The first edition of the Ordnance Survey map for Kilkenny was in 1837 and is held by the County Library.

column1: The elevation is 60 metres (200 ft) above mean sea level. The area of Kilkenny borough is 3.74 square kilometres (1.44 sq mi).

It is 117 kilometres (73 mi) away the capital Dublin and 48 kilometres (30 mi) north from the nearest city Waterford. Wexford is 80 kilometres (50 mi) to the south-east and Limerick is 122 kilometres (76 mi) to the west.

column10: 144 or 11.3%. Overall both the Borough & Environs had a population of 22
column11: 179 in 2006 which was an increase of 1444 persons over the 2002 figure of 20
column12: 735 or 7.0%. People from Kilkenny are often referred to as 'Cats'.

column2: 032 euro and the index of disposable household was 89.4.It is multilingual but predominantly English-speaking
column3: with Irish being the second most commonly spoken language. In recent decades

column1: === Climate ===
The climate of Kilkenny
column2: like the climate of Ireland
column3: is a changeable oceanic climate with few extremes.  It is defined as a temperate oceanic climate
column4: or Cfb on the K√∂ppen climate classification system. Kilkenny lies in plant Hardiness zone 9.

column1: Weatherwise
column2: Kilkenny is generally representative of wide river valleys in the region with low temperatures on cloudless nights
column3: and is significant in that it records some of the highest summer and lowest winter temperatures in Ireland. The highest air temperature ever recorded in Ireland was 33.3 ¬∞C (91.9 ¬∞F)
column4: at Kilkenny Castle on 26 June 1887.The Met √âireann Kilkenny Weather Observing Station
column5: 2 km north-west of the centre of Kilkenny
column6: on the Duningstown Road
column8: and observations ceased in April 2008. A climatological station is currently in operation within 1 km of the old site
column10: was providing live weather data to the general public and climate data to Met √âireann.Extremes recorded at the station include the highest air temperature of 31.5 ¬∞C (88.7 ¬∞F) on 29 June 1976
column11: the lowest air temperature of ‚àí14.1 ¬∞C (6.6 ¬∞F) on 2 January 1979 and the lowest ground temperature of ‚àí18.1 ¬∞C (‚àí0.6 ¬∞F) on 12 January 1982. The maximum daily sunshine was 16.3 hours on 18 June 1978.The warmest and sunniest month on record in Kilkenny was August 1995 with a total of 274.9 hours sunshine and very high temperatures throughout. The maximum daily sunshine was 16.3 hours on 18 June 1978. The overall trend in temperatures has been on the rise with a marked increase from 1988 onwards. Annual temperatures are running over 0.5 degrees or 0.9¬∞F above 20th century levels.The maximum daily rainfall recorded at Kilkenny station was 66.4 millimetres (2.61 in) on 17 July 1983. The late 1950s and early 1960s were wet but rainfall had been steady throughout the century. 2002 was a very wet year and since 2005 annual rainfall has been increased steadily
column12: with 2009 being the wettest year since records commenced in 1958.At the centre of the county
column13: Kilkenny is in a sheltered location
column14: 66 kilometres (41 mi) inland and is surrounded by hills over 200 metres (660 ft)
column15: which ensures that it is not a windy location. The highest wind gust of 77 knots

column1: === Governance ===
Kilkenny is a local electoral area of Kilkenny County Council and includes the electoral divisions of Dunmore
column2: Kilkenny No. 1 Urban
column3: Kilkenny No. 2 Urban
column4: Kilkenny Rural and St. Canice
column5: and elects 7 of the 24 members of the council. This area is also the Municipal District of Kilkenny City. Local government bodies in Kilkenny have responsibility for such matters as planning
column6: roads
column7: sanitation and libraries and are governed by the Local Government Acts 1925 to 2019
column8: the principal act being the Local Government Act 2001.

column1: Kilkenny had previously been governed by a Borough Council
column2: but this was abolished by the Local Government Reform Act 2014. Kilkenny's first council was elected in 1231. From the 13th century to the end of the 16th
column3: the chief magistrate was known as the sovereign
column4: and since then as the mayor. Despite not currently being governed as a city
column5: Kilkenny was historically a city
column6: derived from a royal charter in 1609 by King James I of England and Ireland
column7: and it is both common and permissible to continue to refer to Kilkenny as a city
column8: per Section 10(6) of the Local Government Act 2001
column10: which allows for "the continued use of the description city in relation to Kilkenny
column11: to the extent that that description was used before the establishment day".County Kilkenny is part of the South-East regional authority of Ireland It is part of the Carlow‚ÄìKilkenny D√°il constituency and the South European Parliament constituency.

column1: It was previously represented until 1800 in the Irish House of Commons as Kilkenny City
column2: and in the United Kingdom House of Commons as Kilkenny City from 1801 to 1918
column3: and as part of North Kilkenny from 1918 to 1922. In 1921
column4: the Carlow‚ÄìKilkenny D√°il constituency was created. This continued until 1937
column5: when there was separate Kilkenny constituency
column6: but from 1948 there has been a continuous constituency of Carlow‚ÄìKilkenny.

column1: == Landmarks ==

The Landmarks of Kilkenny show Kilkenny's heritage through the historical buildings. Kilkenny is a well-preserved medieval town and is dominated by both Kilkenny Castle and St. Canice's Cathedral and round tower.
Kilkenny Castle and some important historical architecture of the medieval city survive
column2: like parts of the Kilkenny City Walls. They define the extent
column3: layout and status of the medieval town. The town grew from a monastic settlement to a thriving Norman merchant town in the Middle Ages. Saint Canice's Cathedral and round tower are an example of the monastic settlement. Rothe House on Parliament Street is an example of an Elizabethan merchant townhouse located on the only completely surviving burgage plot in Ireland. It also features a restored 17th century garden on an area of half an acre behind the house
column4: complete with herbs
column5: vegetables and an orchard.

column1: The black stone with decorative white fossils that forms the backbone of many of Kilkenny's fine buildings was quarried locally
column2: particularly from the quarry located 1.6 km south of the town on the R700. Kilkenny Marble was used for the plinth of the new tomb of Richard III in Leicester Cathedral in England.Visitor attractions in Kilkenny and its environs include Kilkenny Castle and Gardens including the Butler Gallery
column3: St. Canice's Cathedral and round tower
column4: Rothe House and Garden
column5: Shee Alms House
column6: Kilkenny Courthouse
column8: Kilkenny City Hall
column12: Kilkenny 'Slips' and St. Francis Abbey Brewery. Smithwick's Experience Castle Park. Gardens include the Castle Rose Garden
column14: the Famine Memorial Garden and the garden of Butler House.

column1: In the county other attractions include Kells Priory
column2: Jerpoint Abbey
column3: Dunmore Caves
column4: Woodstock Estate and Jenkinstown Park.

column1: Local Kilkenny Marble or Black Marble was used to decorate many of the city's buildings
column2: and Kilkenny referred to the "Marble City" for this reason.

column1: === Kilkenny Castle and city walls ===

Kilkenny Castle in Kilkenny city was the seat of the Butler family. (Formerly the family name was FitzWalter.) The castle was sold to the local Castle Restoration Committee in the middle of the 20th century for ¬£50. Shortly afterwards it was handed over to the State
column2: and has since been refurbished and is open to visitors. Part of the collection of the National Art Gallery is on display in the castle. There are ornamental gardens on the north west side of the castle
column3: and extensive land and gardens to the front. It has become one of the most visited tourist sites in Ireland.

column1: The first stone castle was begun in 1204 by William Marshall the site was completed in 1213; it was a symbol of Norman occupation and in its original thirteenth-century condition it would have formed an important element of the defences of the town. There were four large circular corner towers and a massive ditch
column2: part of which can still be seen today on the Parade. This was a square-shaped castle with towers at each corner; three of these original four towers survive to this day.

column1: Kilkenny Walls protected the medieval town of Kilkenny. The town was surrounded by walls with regular towers and gates. Remnants of the Town Walls survive such as Talbot Tower (1207)
column2: which is also known as Talbot's Bastion or Castle. It is the larger of the two surviving towers of the defences of the medieval High town of Kilkenny. There are walls on Abbey Street
column3: and the adjoining Black Freren Gate is the only surviving gate/access remaining on the High town Circuit into the old city. A wall also runs through the brewery's grounds beside St. Francis Abbey.

column1: The Kilkenny City Walls Conservation Plan is a plan by the inhabitants of Kilkenny
column2: Kilkenny Borough Council
column3: the Department of Environment
column4: Heritage and Local Government
column5: An Taisce
column6: The Kilkenny Archaeological Society and The Heritage Council to ensure the long-term survival of the city's walls.

column1: === St. Canice's Cathedral and tower ===
St Canice's Cathedral
column2: also known as Kilkenny Cathedral
column3: present building dates from the 13th century and is the second longest cathedral in Ireland. The cathedral is named after Saint Canice
column4: who also gave his name to the town.Cruciform
column5: the cathedral was built in the Early English
column6: or English Gothic
column8: of limestone
column9: with a low central tower supported on black marble columns. The exterior walls
column12: and there are two small spires at the west end. The cathedral is seventy-five yards long
column13: and its width along the transepts is forty-one yards.

column1: Beside the cathedral stands a 100 ft 9th century round tower. St. Canice's tower an excellent example of a well-preserved early Christian (9th century) Round Tower. Accessible only by a steep set of internal ladders
column2: it may once have been both a watchtower and a refuge
column3: and the summit gives a good view of Kilkenny and the countryside around. The hill on which the cathedral stands is believed to be the centre of the first major settlement at Kilkenny
column4: and the round tower suggests an early ecclesiastical foundation.Dominican Black Abbey was founded in 1225
column5: and lying just off Parliament Street.

column1: === Bridges ===
Kilkenny has four main bridges - Green's Bridge
column2: John's Bridge
column3: the Ossory Bridge and the St Francis Bridge. - and two pedestrian/cycle bridges  - the Lady Desart Bridge and the Ossory Pedestrian Bridge. Each of the bridges spans the River Nore.

column1: Green's Bridge
column2: also known as the 'Great Bridge of Kilkenny'
column3: crosses the River Nore in St. Canices Parish in the townland of Gardens
column4: and is an important element of the architectural heritage of Kilkenny City. First built before 1200
column5: the bridge has been rebuilt several times since the twelfth century due to flooding
column6: including the great floods of 1487 and 1763. The present-day bridge was built in 1766 after the 'Great Flood of 1763'. It was built by William Colles (c. 1710‚Äì70) to designs prepared by George Smith (1763‚Äì67)
column7: a pupil of George Semple (c. 1700‚Äì82).John's Bridge connects John Street to Rose Inn Street in Kilkenny City. It was first built after 1200
column8: and has been called 'John's Bridge' since the Middle Ages. It has also been rebuilt many times since the twelfth century due to flooding. During the flood of 1763
column9: people gathered on John's Bridge after Green's Bridge collapsed. John's Bridge also collapsed
column10: and sixteen people died. The present-day John's Bridge was completed in 1910 and spans 140 ft (43 m) across the River Nore. It was reputedly
column11: at the time it was completed
column12: the longest single-span reinforced bridge in Ireland or Britain. The design was by Mouchel & Partners using the Hennebique system of reinforcement. The arch consists of three ribs
column13: tapering from 2 ft 6 in (0.76 m) to 2 ft (0.61 m) deep. The traverse deck beams are each 2 ft (0.61 m) deep.

column1: The Ossory Bridge
column2: linking the ring-road
column3: was completed in 1984 and features an inlaid sculpture. St Francis Bridge was opened in May 2017
column4: and forms part of the Kilkenny Central Access Scheme. The scheme and the proposed building of the new bridge was the subject of some debate and protest in Kilkenny in 2014.Lady Desart Bridge and Ossory Pedestrian bridge are the city's two pedestrian/cycle bridges. Lady Desart Bridge was opened in January 2014 and links John's Quay and Bateman Quay and is located between John's Bridge and Green's Bridge. The Ossory Pedestrian bridge
column5: located underneath the main Ossory bridge
column6: links the Canal Walk on one side of the River Nore to the Lacken Walk on the other side.

column1: === Old Woollen Mills ===
The Old Woollen Mills was built in the 1800s and is located on the north side of the city
column2: on the Bleach Road. It was one of the largest employers in the area; the site covers 90
column3: 000 square feet (8
column4: 400 m2) and has more than a mile of river frontage onto the Nore. Among its many features is a freestanding red brick chimney
column5: erected in 1905. An architectural salvage and antique yard
column6: Kilkenny Architectural Salvage
column7: is currently located on the site.

column1: == Culture ==
Kilkenny is a popular tourist destination in Ireland. Its art galleries
column2: historic buildings
column3: craft and design workshops
column4: theatre
column5: comedy
column6: public gardens and museums are some of main reasons Kilkenny has become one of Ireland's most visited towns and a base from which to explore the surrounding countryside.

column1: === Arts and festivals ===
Kilkenny is a festival location throughout the year.
Kilkenny Tradfest takes place over the St. Patrick's Day weekend in March and includes the St. Patrick's Day festivities
column2: the parade and the Tradfest music festival
column3: which highlights the best of Irish traditional and folk music.The Kilkenny Roots Festival is held on the first weekend of May and features Americana/Bluegrass/Folk/Rockabilly/AltCountry artists in various indoor venues throughout the city. Since 1998 the festival has attracted musicians from the Americana/Roots genre
column4: including Calexico
column5: Giant Sand
column6: Ryan Adams
column8: Guy Clark
column14: Sturgill Simpson and Alabama Shakes.Kilkenny hosts the annual Cat Laughs comedy festival every June bank holiday week.

column8: sculptures and live performances. Musical events

column1: === Music ===
Music in Kilkenny is a rich and vibrant music scene with traditional Irish Music and artists such as Kerbdog
column2: Engine Alley
column3: R.S.A.G.
column4: My Little Funhouse and groups like Kilkenny Music. Many pubs have Irish traditional music sessions. Kerbdog was an Alternative rock band from Kilkenny who began writing in 1991. Engine Alley is a power pop band

column6: having been signed to U2's Mother Records. R.S.A.G.'s double album Organic Sampler received a Choice Music Prize nomination for Irish Album of the Year 2008 in 2009.The Kilkenny Roots Festival takes place each May Bank Holiday weekend.The Kilkenny Arts Festival is held every August. A concert
column8: is held in Nowlan Park and has attracted musical performers such as Rod Stewart

column1: === Theatre ===
Kilkenny had a tradition of dramatic performance going back to 1366 when the Dublin company set up in Kilkenny. Henry Burkhead printed a play in Kilkenny
column2: Cola's Fury
column3: or Lirenda's Misery (1645)
column4: dealing with events of the Irish Rebellion of 1641 from an English standpoint. It was a blatantly political work with the Lirenda of the title being an anagram of Ireland. In 1642
column5: as a result of the English Civil War
column6: Dublin Royalists were forced to flee the city. Many of them went to Kilkenny to join a confederacy of Old English and Irish that formed in that city.

column1: In 1802 Sir Richard and Sir John Power of Kilfane established the Kilkenny Private Theatre.The Watergate Theatre in Kilkenny is a centre for the performing and visual arts. It provides a varied programme of professional and amateur dramatics
column2: classical and contemporary music
column3: opera and dance
column4: together with exhibitions of paintings and photographs. The Set Theatre is a smaller theatre located on John Street in Kilkenny.

column1: === Film ===
Award-winning animated studio Cartoon Saloon
column2: as well as the film production companies Young Irish Film Makers and Mycrofilms
column3: are all based in Kilkenny. Kilkenny has also hosted the Subtitle European Film Festival each November since 2012.

column1: === Media ===
KCLR radio station serves Carlow and Kilkenny. It is based at both the Broadcast Centre on the Carlow Road
column2: Kilkenny and Exchequer House
column3: Potato Market
column4: Carlow. KCLR is available on 96FM and is an independent local radio station. As of 2009
column5: KCLR had 60% weekly reach and 33% weekday share. KCLR 96FM began broadcasting in May 2004 replacing Radio Kilkenny.

column1: Radio Kilkenny
column2: which began as a pirate station Kilkenny Community Radio
column3: received a licensed to broadcast to Kilkenny city and county on 96.0 MHz
column4: 96.6 MHz and 106.3 MHz in 1988. Radio Kilkenny had 63% of the radio listeners in County Kilkenny and 16% in County Carlow but failed to secure a franchise in 2003 when the Broadcasting Commission of Ireland changed the station's franchise area to include Carlow. The station ceased broadcasting at 2:10 a.m. on 1 January 2004.Beat 102-103 is a regional youth radio station broadcasting across the South East of Ireland. It serves a population of about 450
column6: and in August 2006 it had a 49% share of the south east market.

column1: ==== Print media ====
Newspapers have been produced in Kilkenny for centuries. Longstanding examples include Finns Leinster Journal (later the Kilkenny Journal) from 1767 to 1965
column2: the Kilkenny People from 1916 to 1992
column3: and the Kilkenny Moderator from 1814 to 1916. Other papers included the Leinster Independent from 1872; the Kilkenny Chronicle from 1813; the Kilkenny Courier; Tipperary Examiner from 1858; the Kilkenny Express and the Wexford Express from 1875; The Post (a sister paper to Kilkenny People) from 1926; the Kilkenny Standard from 1979
column4: the Kilkenny People in 1895
column5: The Kilkenny Voice (2005-2008) and also the Kilkenny Advertiser.Finn's Leinster Journal (1767‚Äì1801) was founded by Edmund Finn in 1767. It was published in Kilkenny but some content was relevant to Carlow. It was continued as Leinster Journal (1801‚Äì1830) and the Kilkenny Journal from 1832.The Moderator (1814‚Äì1822) changed its name to Kilkenny Moderator 1822‚Äì1919 and reverted to Moderator from 1920‚Äì1925.

column1: The modern Kilkenny People was first published in 1895. It is a weekly paper. According to the Audit Bureau of Circulations
column2: the Kilkenny People had an average weekly circulation of 17
column3: 578 for the first six months of 2006. It is printed by the Kilkenny People Group at Purcellsinch and the group also publishes a number of other regional papers.

column1: ==== Photography ====
Photographic Collections of Kilkenny include the Lawrence Collection c. 1900
column2: the Crawford Collection c. 1940
column3: the Valentine Collection c. 1950
column4: the Bolton Street Students' Survey c. 1970
column5: the Industrial Archaeologica Survey c. 1989
column6: the Carrigan Collection and the St. John's Parish Collection
column7: as well as many historical postcards.

column1: === Community ===
==== Awards ====
Kilkenny was named as the Academy of Urbanism European Great Town for 2008. The Academy Chairman
column2: John Thompson
column3: said "it is great to have an Irish town coming through in this year's awards
column4: especially Kilkenny which is coming to terms with economic growth without losing its wonderful character and humour". Kilkenny won the Irish Tidy Towns Competition in 1985.

column1: ==== Twinned cities ====
Kilkenny is twinned with Moret-sur-Loing in France
column2: and Formigine in Italy.

column1: == Infrastructure ==
=== Education ===
Kilkenny is the home of many noted secondary schools
column2: including the Church of Ireland Kilkenny College
column3: founded in 1538. This is one of the oldest schools in the country
column4: and its past pupils include Jonathan Swift and George Berkeley.

column1: A quote from an article "The Berkeley Pavilion" by Patsy Dempsey ‚Äì Bishop George Berkeley (1685‚Äì1753) was one of the great philosophers of his time. He was born near Kilkenny and lived in Dysart Castle
column2: Thomastown. Berkeley studied at Kilkenny College (now County Hall) from 1696‚Äì1700
column3: where Jonathan Swift was a predecessor.

column1: St. Kieran's College was founded in 1782 and was the first Roman Catholic secondary school in Ireland. It was created after Grattan's Parliament which permitted some relaxation of the Penal Laws in the country. There are a number of other second-level schools
column2: including Loreto Secondary School
column3: CBS Kilkenny
column4: Col√°iste Pobail Osra√≠
column5: Presentation College and the Kilkenny City Vocational School. Other schools located in the rural areas of the county are Castlecomer Community School
column6: Colaiste Mhuire Johnstown
column8: St. Brigid's Callan
column9: Grennan College Thomastown and Callan CBS. These also are noted for their focus on the games of hurling and camogie. Gaelscoil Osrai an Irish school in Kilkenny
column10: is the 2nd largest Irish-only school in Ireland with around 450 from Junior Infants to 6th Class.

column1: Maynooth University maintained a campus at the grounds of St. Kieran's College from September 1997 until June 2018.  The university offered the first year of full-time arts degrees in Kilkenny
column2: with students attending second and third year courses on the main campus in Maynooth.

column1: === Roads ===
The national primary routes serving Kilkenny include the N10 (connecting to the M9 motorway Dublin/Carlow/Waterford route)
column2: the N77 (connecting to Portlaise and the M7 motorway)
column3: and N76 (connecting to Clonmel).

column1: === Railway ===
Kilkenny railway station opened on 12 May 1848. Kilkenny acquired railway links to Dublin in 1850
column2: Waterford in 1854
column3: Portlaoise in 1876 and Castlecomer in 1919. C√≥ras Iompair √âireann closed the Castlecomer and Kilkenny Junction lines in 1962. Kilkenny railway station was renamed McDonagh Station in 1966 after the Irish nationalist
column4: poet and playwright Thomas MacDonagh. Kilkenny remains an important stop on Iarnr√≥d √âireann's Intercity route between Dublin and Waterford.

column1: Unlike other countries
column2: the location of railway stations in Ireland was closely related to military matters rather than trade or public transport. Kilkenny railway station is a fine example of this peculiarity
column3: with Stephens Barracks being closely positioned to the railway station.

column1: From Kilkenny station trains run on the Dublin-Waterford line
column2: providing connections in Waterford to Clonmel and stations to Limerick Junction. At Kildare connecting trains provide links to Ballina
column3: Westport
column4: Galway
column5: Ennis
column6: Ballybrophy
column8: Limerick

column1: Kilkenny Airport is only used for private flying. The nearest airports with scheduled services are Dublin Airport and Cork Airport
column2: which are both in the region of 150 km away.

column1: === Industry ===

The city has a history of brewing and was home to St. Francis Abbey Brewery which was founded in the early 18th century by Messrs Cole and Smithwick. The Guinness Ireland Group owned this brewery from the 1960s. At the beginning of the 21st century
column2: Guinness merged with Grand Metropolitan plc to form Diageo
column3: the world's largest alcoholic beverage business
column4: and the brewery became part of Diageo Global Supply. In its final years
column5: Smithwick's Ale formed only a small percentage of production there. Another product was Kilkenny ale
column6: a close relation of Smithwicks ale. Some 80% of beer produced at the brewery was Budweiser
column7: a brand not owned by Diageo
column8: but produced under licence. Diageo announced in May 2008 the closure of St. Francis Abbey Brewery
column9: which took place on 31 December 2013. Production was then moved to St. James's Gate Brewery

column1: ==== Cooperatives ====
Kilkenny is also home to the head offices of Glanbia
column2: one of the world's top dairy companies. Glanbia was formed by the merger of two dairy businesses: Avonmore and Waterford Foods and has interests in Ireland
column3: the United Kingdom
column4: the United States and more than 30 other countries.

column1: County Kilkenny Village Creameries amalgamated to create the Avonmore Creameries brand in 1966. That coop became Avonmore Food plc in 1988 and joined with Waterford Food plc in 1997. It is today known as the global Food giant
column2: Glanbia
column3: one of the world's top nutrition companies
column4: with revenues of over ‚Ç¨3.5 billion and 5
column5: 815 employees.In 1966 over 30 local creameries created by local farmers joined with other small rural co-operative societies throughout County Kilkenny and some neighbouring counties
column6: and together with Unigate Limited support
column7: formed the Avonmore Creameries Federation Realising the benefits of increased scale and greater diversification in the 1960s
column8: they saw the need for an amalgamation of many small
column9: locally focused co-operatives across Ireland. It led to the construction of a new multi-purpose Avonmore dairy plant facility in Ballyragget
column11: a plant they claimed was the biggest food processing facility in Europe at that time. Today that giant global entity is known as Glanbia. Glanbia has its origins in the Irish agricultural co-operative movement that evolved over the last century
column12: ever since first Irish Co-operative founded by Horace Plunkett in 1889. Today Glanbia has operations in 34 countries and is exporting to more than 100 countries worldwide. Glanbia is ranked by revenue (2010 figures) in the top 100 Cooperatives
column13: No 98 in the world and No 1 in Ireland by the International Co-operative Alliance
column14: the global apex organisation of co-operatives worldwide.

column1: According to the Glanbia Collections in Kilkenny Archives at St Kieran's College
column2: Kilkenny
column3: the Avonmore Coop brand was created through the merger of the following Village Creameries: Ballingarry Co-Operative Creamery Ltd.
column4: Ballyhale Co-Operative Creamery Dairy Society Ltd.
column5: Ballypatrick Co-Operative Creamery Ltd.
column6: Avonmore Creameries Ltd.
column8: Bennettsbridge Co-Operative Creamery Ltd.
column9: Callan Co-op Creamery and Dairy Society Ltd.
column13: Dungarvan Co Waterford Co-Operative Creamery Ltd.
column15: Glenmore County Kilkenny Co-Operative Creamery Ltd.
column16: Graiguecullen County Carlow Corn & Coal Co. Ltd.
column19: County Kilkenny Co-Operative Agricultural & Dairy Society Ltd.
column24: Loughcullen County Kilkenny Co-Operative Creamery Ltd.
column26: Knockavendagh & Moyglass Killenaule Co-Operative Creamery Society Ltd.
column27: Muckalee County Kilkenny Co-Operative Dairy Society Ltd.

column1: The Ballyhale C.D.S. (1895‚Äì1995) 100th anniversary booklet of its foundation records that a federation of 25 Co-op Creameries originally emerged in January 1965 under the umbrella of Avonmore Creameries Ltd.
column2: that shares were taken in the new entity by the society and that in following years a Ballyragget milk processing factory was built. Ireland entered the Common Market in 1970. The first bulk milk collections tool place from 1973
column3: when the amalgamation was formalised. Ballyhale C.D.S. became one of 20 members of Avonmore Farmers Ltd.; the other founding members being Castlehale
column4: Mullinavat
column5: Iverk
column6: Piltown
column8: Kilmacow

column1: Recent developments in Kilkenny have attracted further investment from local businesses as well as attracting new industry. Leggetsrath Business Park was opened in 2003. There are two retail warehouse parks in Kilkenny: Kilkenny Retail Park and Ormonde Retail Park. Hebron Business Park was constructed in 2002 and is a privately owned extension to the Hebron Industrial Estate
column2: the main centre for industry in Kilkenny.

column1: === Hospitals ===

Hospitals in Kilkenny include three public hospitals and one private hospital. St. Luke's is a general medical and surgical hospital built in 1942. It is based on Freshford Road and provides a range of local and regional services. Local services include medical
column2: general surgery
column3: obstetrics
column4: gynaecology and paediatrics. St. Canice's is a psychiatric hospital
column5: opened in 1852 and located on the Dublin Road. It provides a range of mental health services including acute and long stay care
column6: out-patient services throughout the county
column8: respite care community hostel facilities and day care facilities. It also provides paediatric physiotherapy
column9: and occupational therapy. Kilcreene is the regional orthopaedic hospital outside the city in Kilcreene. Aut Even is a private hospital based outside Kilkenny City.

column1: == Sport ==
=== Athletics ===

The Kilkenny City Harriers Club is an athletics club formed in 1953. In 1989 Kilkenny was designated as a local sports centre and an all-weather running track and facilities designed to meet International Association of Athletics Federations standards was begun. In 1992 the new track was officially opened and renamed Scanlon Park after Patrick 'Rusty' Scanlon
column2: who had been associated with the old complex both as an athlete and as a soccer player.

column1: The County Board of Kilkenny GAA (Irish: Cumann L√∫thchleas Gael Coiste Cill Channaigh) has its head office and main grounds at Nowlan Park in the city. The Kilkenny branch of the GAA was founded in 1887.
Hurling is the dominant sport in the city and county
column2: and Kilkenny has one of the most successful county hurling teams. Secondary schools noted for their contribution to the game include St. Kieran's College and Christian Brothers School (CBS). Former students who have played for St. Kieran's include Eddie Keher
column3: Brian Cody
column4: Eoin Kelly
column5: DJ Carey and Henry Shefflin. There are three GAA clubs based in the city: O'Loughlin Gaels GAA
column6: Dicksboro GAA and James Stephens (GAA Club). St John's Parish is the catchment area for O'Loughlin Gaels. The parishes of St Mary's and St Canice's are associated with Dicksboro. St Patrick's parish is the catchment area for the James Stephens club.Gaelic football is also played in Kilkenny
column7: although it is not as popular as it is in some other Irish counties. The Kilkenny footballers are the only county not to participate in the All-Ireland Senior Football Championship. They have previously taken gap years away from League football
column8: and for example did not participate in 2013

column1: === Association Football ===
Kilkenny City AFC played in the League of Ireland until January 2008. It entered the league as EMFA in 1986
column2: but resigned their position in the league after 22 years citing "lack of finance
column3: poor results and paltry attendances". The club had spent all but two seasons in the League of Ireland's second tier. Kilkenny and District Soccer League run leagues at schoolboy
column4: youths and junior level throughout the county. It is affiliated to Leinster Football Association
column5: Football Association of Ireland and the Schoolboy's Football Association of Ireland.In 2015 Kilkenny United W.F.C. were admitted to the Women's National League
column6: the top tier of women's football in Ireland.

column1: === Rugby ===
Kilkenny RFC founded in 1885
column2: is a very strong and successful Rugby Union club based at Foulkstown on the Waterford Road. The club has provided many players for the Ireland team including Ernie Ridgeway
column3: Bill Tector
column4: Jack Notley
column5: Willie Duggan
column6: Ned Byrne
column7: Ronan Kearney and Gary Halpin. Ian Dowling plays for the Munster Rugby team and is a two-time winner of the European Rugby Cup in 2006 and 2008.Jack Rafferty led the team to several notable victories in 1966.Rugby is played at schools level by Kilkenny College and Kilkenny Christian Brothers School (CBS).

column1: === Golf ===
Kilkenny Golf Club is an 18-hole championship parkland course within the city to the North West
column2: close to the city centre. It has hosted several Professional Championship events. In 1984 and 1996
column3: it was the venue for the All Ireland Mixed Foursome Finals
column4: and in 1985 hosted the All Ireland Cups and Shields Finals. It is playable all year round due to sand-based greens. The course is mostly flat terrain with an abundance of trees.

column1: Around Kilkenny City there is also a Driving Range in Newpark and an 18-hole all-weather Par 3 golf course in Pocoke.
Mount Juliet Golf Course is a golf resort situated near Kilkenny in Thomastown. Jack Nicklaus designed the course
column2: and it is considered to be one of Ireland's best courses.

column1: === Ice hockey ===
Kilkenny City Storm is a mixed ice hockey team which was formed in 2007
column2: and plays in the Irish Ice Hockey Association Recreational Division League. The team also has an inline hockey team
column3: playing in the Northern Inline Hockey League and the Irish inline hockey (roller hockey) league.
